;;2022 年 9 月，巴基斯坦信德省，人们从被洪水淹没的家中打捞出财物。
;

;一份严厉的联合国报告警告说，世界对已经影响全球数十亿人的气候危机不断升级的影响“严重”准备不足。

;

;国际资金用于保护社区免受热浪、洪水和气候影响。干旱仅能满足当今需求的 5-10%，而且近年来实际需求量有所下降，而极端天气的打击更为严重。

;

;联合国环境规划署 (Unep) 的报告估计，干旱所需的资金在 2,150 亿至 3,870 亿美元之间仅在这十年中，贫穷和脆弱国家就需要一年的时间来适应气候变化。然而，报告称，2021 年资金减少了 15%，仅为 210 亿美元。

;

;富裕国家在 2021 年格拉斯哥联合国气候峰会上承诺，到 2025 年提供 400 亿美元。提供适应措施保护人们免受气候影响是 ;Cop28 峰会的首要任务;，该峰会将于阿拉伯联合酋长国 11 月 30 日，同时减少碳排放。

;

;适应具有很高的成本效益，例如，每投资 10 亿美元用于预防沿海洪水，就能减少 140 亿美元的经济损失，报道称。此外，保护措施将限制未来通过新的;最近的适应计划在确保保护生命和生计方面“远远不够”;，目前正在;在法庭上受到质疑;。

;

;“作为一个文明，我们准备不足 – 我们不'联合国环境规划署执行主任英格·安德森 (Inger Andersen) 表示：“如果没有足够的规划或投资，我们所有人都会面临风险。” “2023 年，气候变化再次变得更具破坏性和致命性。我们亲眼目睹了这些证据，并一次又一次地在电视屏幕上看到了这些证据。”她强调了;欧洲的洪水;和;中国;，;酷热;和;美国和加拿大的野火;，以及;东非干旱;。

;

;安徒生说适应资金的下降非常令人担忧：“这对那些在没有任何保护的情况下面临气候影响的全部力量的人们产生了巨大的影响。”在限制损失和损害时，她说：“离开[适应]的时间越长，痛苦就会越大。”

;

;她说杰出的适应科学家是萨利穆尔·胡克教授，他< a href="https://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2023/nov/01/a-titan-of-the-climate-movement-tributes-pour-in-for-saleemul-huq">;去世上周;，并表示他的;引自 6 月;：“我们现在正处于气候变化造成损失和损害的时代。从现在开始的每一天、每一周、每一月、每一年，各地的情况都会变得更糟。每个国家都会受到打击，每个国家都在某种程度上没有做好准备。”

;

;联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯表示：“生命和生计正在丧失和破坏，弱势群体受害最深。然而，随着需求的增加，行动却陷入停滞。世界必须采取行动缩小适应差距并实现气候正义。

;

;“化石燃料大亨及其推动者助长了这一混乱局面；他们必须支持那些因此而受苦的人，[因此]我呼吁各国政府对化石燃料行业的暴利征税，”他说。

;

;智库 E3G 的汤姆·埃文斯 (Tom Evans) 表示：“适应是一个问题面对日益严重和频繁的气候影响，生存的问题。长期以来，这些复杂而艰巨的任务被忽视了。”

;

;他补充道：“但是，随着气候灾难来得比预期更快、更严重，这种短期主义需要停止。数十亿人应对气候崩溃的能力取决于政治领导人是否更加认真地对待这一议程。”

;

;;环境署报告;总结道：“目前的气候行动远远不足以实现《巴黎协定》的温度和适应目标。”报告称，仅 55 个气候最脆弱国家在过去 20 年就遭受了超过 5000 亿美元的损失：“这些成本将在未来几十年急剧上升，特别是在没有强有力的[减排]的情况下。”

;
;

;;相关：;;研究估计，极端天气造成的气候危机每小时造成 1600 万美元的损失;

;
;

;所需的保护措施包括沿海防御（海平面上升威胁数百万人）和城市防洪，暴风雨变得更加猛烈。安德森说，城市需要更好地适应热浪，农业也需要适应更多的干旱。

;

;她说，增加和恢复绿地面积非常重要，哥伦比亚麦德林的绿色走廊减少了例如，温度降低 2 摄氏度，红树林提供沿海风暴保护。 ;向人们发出极端天气警报的预警系统;也至关重要，联合国的目标是到 2028 年覆盖地球上的每个人。< /p>;

;报告发现，超过80%的国家至少有一项国家适应计划，但安德森表示，关键是动员投资为这些计划提供资金。报告称，世界银行和其他国际金融机构进行改革以提供更多气候资金，各国政府和企业增加支出也很重要。

;

;报告还表示，损失和损害的成本可能会大幅增长，这意味着创新的融资来源，例如航空税和;运输;和债务减免，需要探索。安德森说：“其中一些在某些圈子里非常有争议，但现实是成本越来越高，因此我们需要寻找所有机会。”

;

;化石燃料的燃烧是气候紧急情况的主要原因。英国前首相戈登·布朗最近呼吁;每年对飙升的石油和天然气利润征收 250 亿美元的全球暴利税，由沙特阿拉伯等最富有的石油国家缴纳阿拉伯联合酋长国和挪威。 “[他们]可以轻松支付得起，”他说。 “未能将这些成果的一小部分回收到世界上最贫穷的国家是我们这个时代的最大丑闻之一。”

;;在新南威尔士州溪流中的一根圆木旁边发现了一只白体鸭嘴兽，上面有一只海龟
;< p>;研究人员正在寻找;濒危海龟;发现了更罕见的东西——一只在新南威尔士州溪流中嬉戏的白色鸭嘴兽。

;

;这种非凡生物的照片和镜头已被公开在过去两年左右的时间里多次遭遇后，该发现已在科学期刊上发表。

;

;新英格兰大学博士生卢·斯特里廷 (Lou Streeting) 第一次发现濒临灭绝的西部锯壳龟时，正在北高地溪流中搜寻2021 年初引人注目的谜团。

;
;

;;相关：;;环保主义者谴责澳大利亚在 48 种植物和动物被添加到受威胁物种名单后的“糟糕记录”< /a>;

;
;

;UNE 研究人员发现了一种罕见的白色鸭嘴兽，生活在新南威尔士州北部的一条小溪中。

;

;“它浮出水面，距离我们只有几米远，我们当时就发现了它。”就像‘哇，我们刚刚看到一只白色鸭嘴兽吗？’”Streeting 说道。

;

;“我很高兴在视频中捕捉到了它，因为我认为否则没有人会相信我。”

;

;从那时起，她多次看到鸭嘴兽，最近一次是三个月前，表明它正在应对缺乏伪装的情况。

;

;一只有一点差异的鸭嘴兽

; < p>;过去曾有过白色鸭嘴兽的记录，但这只有一点不同。

;

;它不是白化病，因为只有其身体的一部分受到黑色素（一种产生颜色的色素）缺乏的影响。皮毛、皮肤和眼睛。

;

;

;“它确实有一些色素沉着。它有黑色的喙，黑色的脚，尾巴上有一点颜色。所以我们说它是白种鸭嘴兽。”

;

;这可能是第一个有记录的鸭嘴兽。

; ;

;“我们对科学文献、报纸和数据库的搜索得出了 12 条白化或非典型白色鸭嘴兽的单独记录，可以追溯到 1997 年的第一个记录。 1835 年，我们的观察可能代表了唯一已知的白种鸭嘴兽记录。”

;

;斯特里廷希望这一有趣的发现能够提醒每个人有必要保护国家水道中的本土物种宝库。

;

; p>;

;“这些环境不仅是西部锯甲龟等濒危物种的家园，也是其他真正独特和非凡的生物的家园，例如这种罕见的白色鸭嘴兽。”

;

;栖息地破坏加剧了物种的衰退数字

;

;澳大利亚保护基金会表示;鸭嘴兽;的数量正在下降，鸭嘴兽、产蛋、产奶但无乳头的特性使其数量减少了约四分之一过去 30 年里栖息地的数量不断减少。

;

;尽管呈下降趋势，但仍缺乏良好的数据，而且只能粗略估计剩余数量。

;

;为了弥补这一差距， ACF 与新南威尔士大学生态系统科学中心合作开展了一项名为 Platy 项目的公民科学计划。

;

;

;它鼓励澳大利亚人在当地的小溪和河流中寻找它们，并分享任何目击事件的详细信息。

;

;鸭嘴兽会在澳大利亚消失吗？

;

;新南威尔士大学保护生态学家 Gilad Bino 参与了 2021 年国家评估;鸭嘴兽的保护状况;，并表示目前还剩下多少只存在很大的不确定性。

;

;它的数量可能在 50,000 到 300,000 之间。

;

;尽管有证据表明大墨尔本等地的种群数量正在减少，但仍然没有针对该物种的国家或州级监测框架。

;

;“对于所有城市地区都是如此，但我们没有数据，”他说。

;

;墨累-达令河系统部分地区的种群数量也在下降，布里斯班也出现了局部灭绝。

;

;“在南澳大利亚，除了袋鼠岛上引入的种群外，它们几乎已经灭绝，甚至它们也受到了丛林大火和干旱的影响，”他说。

;

;“我认为鸭嘴兽不会在接下来的几十年里消失——我希望我是对的。但我真正担心的是，对于澳大利亚各地的许多人来说，他们将看到它们从当地河流中消失。”

; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 15:22:01 +0800 Iranian mother jailed for 13 years after denouncing death of son shot at protesthttps://www.theguardian.com/global-development/2023/nov/02/iran-mother-mahsa-yazdani-jailed-13-years-after-denouncing-death-of-son-shot-at-protest

;;Mahsa Yazdani 和她的儿子 Mohammad Javad Zahedi
;

;伊朗的一位母亲，她的儿子是据报道，她在社交媒体上要求为孩子伸张正义后，被安全部队多次近距离射击后被伊朗法院判处 13 年监禁。

;

;Mahsa Yazdani，20 岁据人权组织和家庭成员称，长子穆罕默德·贾瓦德·扎赫迪 (Mohammad Javad Zahedi) 在 2022 年 9 月的反政权抗议活动中被杀，并因亵渎、煽动、侮辱最高领袖和散布反政权宣传等罪名被定罪。他们说她将服刑前五年，不得假释。

;

;在 ;年轻的马赫萨·阿米尼 (Mahsa Amini) 在拘留期间死亡;因未正确佩戴头巾而被伊朗“道德警察”逮捕的库尔德妇女。

;

;据扎赫迪的家人称，扎赫迪的背部和头部被近距离枪击数次。 ;法医报告;证实他是被大量猎枪子弹杀死的.

; ;

;儿子被杀后，亚兹达尼公开谴责该政权对抗议者的袭击，并呼吁为她的儿子和其他在示威活动中丧生的人伸张正义。 8 月 22 日，她在家中被捕后，很快就受到了审判和判刑。

;

;判决消息发布几小时后，亚兹达尼的女儿 Mitra Zahedi 在 Instagram 上分享了一篇帖子，内容如下：“我三岁的弟弟会怎样？谁应对这一切残忍行为负责？”

;

;针对定罪和长期监禁，;伊朗人权中心; 说：“我们强烈谴责 Mahsa Yazdani 的可耻判决，她是一位悲伤的母亲，为她的儿子寻求正义。”

;

;它补充说：“伊朗数百名母亲被阻止为她们被谋杀的亲人伸张正义。 ”

;

;宣判之际，伊朗当局似乎正在积极追捕抗议期间遇难者的家人。民权组织 ; 的斯凯拉·汤普森 (Skylar Thompson) 表示，亚兹达尼的判决是“当局对受害者家属施加无情压力的又一个明显迹象”。伊朗的人权活动家;。

;

;2023 年 5 月，;Abolfazl Adinezadeh;，一名被安全部队枪杀的 17 岁青少年，据报道，被指控“反政府宣传”给他们的律师。一位消息人士告诉《卫报》，此后，这个家庭一直受到该政权特工的持续搜查和威胁。

;

;人权活动人士也对马沙拉·卡拉米 (Mashallah Karami) 表示担忧。 ;穆罕默德·迈赫迪·卡拉米 (Mohammad Mehdi Karami) 的父亲，22 岁的空手道冠军，于 1 月被处决在街头抗议中被捕，并被指控杀害一名保安人员。

;

;他的父亲在儿子被处决前曾公开为儿子求饶，并在社交媒体上呼吁为他和其他年轻抗议者伸张正义，据报道，他已于 8 月被捕，据信仍被拘留。

;

;《卫报》采访了在 2022 年头巾抗议活动中被杀或被捕的抗议者的几位家人，他们表示，随着政权试图进一步逮捕和定罪，他们担心会遭到进一步逮捕和定罪。让家人保持沉默。

;
;

;;相关：;;伊朗的马赫萨·阿米尼 (Mahsa Amini) 荣获欧盟萨哈罗夫人权奖;

;
;

;一位不愿透露姓名的近亲表示， ;Kumar Daroftadeh;，16 岁2022 年 10 月被安全部队杀害的 7 岁女孩说：“母亲们因为被政权谋杀的儿子寻求正义而受到迫害。我们是一个用鲜血换来自由的国家。

;

;“我们将继续为失去的亲人而战，因为威胁无法洗刷鲜血。我赞扬像 Mahsa Yazdani 这样勇敢的母亲，她们让斗争继续下去。”

;

; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 14:22:02 +0800 Global heating is accelerating, warns scientist who sounded climate alarm in the 80shttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/nov/02/heating-faster-climate-change-greenhouse-james-hansen
;;2023-11-02T04:01:28Z;
;
;;开裂的土壤日落景观
;

;全球变暖的速度比目前理解的要快，并且将导致这种情况最早向世界发出温室效应警报的美国科学家詹姆斯·汉森领导的研究表明，这一关键温度阈值将在本十年内突破。

;

;地球气候对人类活动更加敏感。所造成的变化超出了科学家迄今为止所意识到的水平，这意味着将释放出“危险”的热量爆发，这将使世界在 2020 年代内比工业化前时期的平均温度高 1.5 摄氏度，在 2020 年代将比工业化前时期平均高 2 摄氏度。 2050 年，;周四发表的论文;预测。

;
;

;;相关：;;“我们都是该死的傻瓜”：拉响气候警报的科学家80 年代警告更糟糕的情况即将到来;

;
;

;全球变暖的速度令人震惊，这意味着世界将突破巴黎气候协议中规定的国际商定的 1.5 摄氏度阈值汉森领导的这项研究表明，世界可能比预期早得多，“人类难以忍受，极端气候更加严重”;这位前美国宇航局科学家在 20 世纪 80 年代向美国国会发出了关于气候变化的基本警告;。

;

;汉森说，有由于化石燃料的持续燃烧，大量的全球供暖“正在酝酿之中”，而地球对此的影响“非常敏感”——远不止于此 ;比联合国政府间气候变化专门委员会 (IPCC) 提出的最佳估计敏感;。

;

;“如果我们没有预料到全球变暖会加速，那么我们就是该死的傻瓜和糟糕的科学家，”汉森说。 “我们开始受到浮士德式交易的影响。这就是为什么全球变暖的速度正在加快。”

;

;全球变暖的速度是否正在加快的问题一直很尖锐;今年，在连续数月破纪录的气温中，科学家们展开了争论;。

;

;汉森指出，来自太阳的能量与来自地球的输出能量之间的不平衡“显着增加”，在过去十年中几乎翻了一番。他警告说，这种上升可能会给世界沿海城市带来灾难性的海平面上升。

;

;这项新研究由汉森和其他十几位科学家经过同行评审的工作组成，认为这不平衡、地球对气候的敏感性更高以及;减少; 航运造成的污染减少了空气中反射阳光的硫颗粒的数量，导致全球变暖加剧。

;

;“我们正处于气候紧急情况的早期阶段，”该论文警告。 “对于已经远远失去平衡的气候系统来说，这种加速是危险的。扭转这一趋势至关重要——我们必须为地球降温——以保护海岸线并拯救世界沿海城市。”

;

;为了应对这场危机，汉森和他的同事主张征收全球碳税更有争议的是，故意向大气中喷洒硫磺，以将热量从地球转移出去，人为降低世界温度。

;

;所谓的“太阳能地球工程”已成为;因威胁对环境造成潜在连锁危害而受到广泛批评;，因为以及如果停止注入硫就会产生鞭打加热效应的风险，但得到了少数科学家的支持，他们警告说，世界已经没有时间和选择来避免灾难性的温度上升。

;

;汉森表示，虽然减排应该是重中之重，但“由于开发充足的无碳能源进展缓慢，而且未能对碳排放定价，我们现在不太可能实现这一目标——年轻人的光明未来– 从这里开始，无需太阳辐射管理的临时帮助”。

;

;;今年;几乎肯定是有可靠记录的最热的一年，九月份的气温;被一位气候研究人员描述为;“令人惊叹的香蕉”。 ;本周的一份报告发现;碳预算限制了由于化石燃料的持续燃烧和森林砍伐，全球 1.5 摄氏度的供暖现已几乎耗尽。

;

;但是，尽管科学家们清楚这是全球变暖上升趋势的一部分，但目前还没有一致认为这一趋势正在加速。

;

;宾夕法尼亚大学气候科学家迈克尔·曼 (Michael Mann) 表示，汉森和他的合著者在确定地表加热加速方面“非常脱离主流”这种情况“在过去几十年里一直以非常稳定的速度持续”。曼恩表示，减少航运排放对气候系统的影响很小，对太阳能地球工程的呼吁是误导性的，而且是“非常滑坡”。

;

;哥伦比亚大学古气候学家巴贝尔·霍尼施 (Bärbel Hönisch) 表示，她对汉森关于数百万年前地球气候状况的研究中所表达的确定性持“一些保留”，该研究有助于预测当今变暖的后果。 “我会更保守一点，但他们很可能是正确的——这是一篇写得很好的论文，”她说。 “它提出了很多问题，这些问题将引发大量研究，从而推动我们的理解。”

;

;其他一些研究人员对汉森关于全球变暖的可怕警告不那么怀疑，强调了他之前的有先见之明的警告气候危机在很大程度上是由于几十年来在阻止化石燃料的使用方面不采取行动而造成的。

;

;“我认为 [Hansen] 认为 IPCC 在某种程度上低估了气候敏感性的论点将被证明是正确的，”斯坦福大学科学家、全球碳项目主席罗布·杰克逊说。 “很难知道在变暖方面什么是不可能发生的。全球范围内还没有化石燃料的使用量下降，甚至煤炭也没有。

;

;“我认为汉森的悲观情绪是有道理的。 35 年前，他站出来敲响了警钟，而世界却大多忽视了他，也忽视了我们所有人。”

; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 13:52:01 +0800 ‘A huge event’: excitement as the Beatles’ final song Now and Then approaches releasehttps://www.theguardian.com/music/2023/nov/02/excitement-beatles-final-song-now-and-then-release-ai
;;2023-11-02T05:00:31Z;
;
;;1967 年 5 月的披头士乐队。
;

;乔治·哈里森最初不喜欢它；现在，它已成为现实。粉丝们长期以来一直认为它永远不会发行。但披头士乐队的“最后”歌曲《Now and Then》将于格林威治标准时间下午 2 点发行，这对于英国最伟大的乐队来说是一个意想不到的最后繁荣。

;

;“这是一个重要的时刻，”博士说 ;利物浦大学的 Holly Tessler;，专门研究披头士乐队的历史和遗产。 “一支 50 多年前解散的乐队告诉你这是我们的最后一首歌，这感觉很奇怪……在某种程度上，80 多岁的保罗和林戈正在划清界限。我怀疑对于几乎所有披头士乐队的粉丝来说，这是一个非常甜蜜的时刻；感觉就像一个结局。所以我认为这很重要。”

;

;这首歌的音乐来自于乐队所有四位成员的贡献，包括已故乔治·哈里森 (George Harrison) 于 1995 年录制的吉他，以及约翰·列侬 (John Lennon) 的演唱，这些声音取材于歌曲的原版晚期作品。 70 年代演示。这首歌是列侬在纽约达科他大楼的家中创作并演唱的，他于 1980 年在那里被谋杀。

; ;

;然后，1994 年，小野洋子 (Yoko Ono)列侬的遗孀将演示版交给了保罗·麦卡特尼，装在标有“献给保罗”的录音带中。它还包含列侬为歌曲《Free As a Bird》和《Real Love》演唱的歌曲，这些歌曲由麦卡特尼、哈里森和林戈·斯塔尔创作完成，并于 1995 年作为披头士乐队多媒体档案项目 Anthology 的一部分发行。但哈里森的遗孀奥利维亚表示，乔治“感觉[时不时]的技术问题是无法克服的，并得出结论，不可能以足够高的标准完成赛道”。 It has been shelved ever since.

;

;;Philip Norman;, who has written biographies of Lennon, McCartney and Harrison as well as the acclaimed Shout! The True Story of the Beatles, explains: “Strangely enough it was always George Harrison who was at heads with Paul McCartney about releasing this song during the 1990s; George had previously said it was not good enough to release. Now with AI it has been brought technologically up to date.”

;

;That AI tech has been used to better isolate Lennon's voice – though McCartney has been at pains to confirm “nothing has been artificially or synthetically created. It's all real and we all play on it.” The Lennon vocal was then folded into new parts for the song recorded by McCartney and Starr, and guitar lines recorded by Harrison in 1995, plus a new string arrangement.

;

;Olivia Harrison said George “would have wholeheartedly joined Paul and Ringo in completing the recording of Now and Then”. McCartney has called the project “quite emotional”, adding: “In 2023, to still be working on Beatles music, and about to release a new song the public haven't heard, I think it's an exciting thing.”

;

;Norman calls the release “a huge event”, but believes that despite the benefits of AI technology for voice and quality enhancement, Now and Then won't capture the energy and sense of unity that can be heard in other Beatles songs. “They really had the 'group mind', which psychologists talk about; they artistically coexisted as an organism together. I don't think it will capture that.”

;

;He hasn't heard it, but believes Now and Then, originally written alone by Lennon, will therefore deviate from the traditional Beatles sound. “John Lennon wasn't normally a lead vocalist – they were always very unified as a band,” he says. “It was the greatest quality they had, and it's what made the breakup so tragic. They had the choral male sound, and that was unusual before the Beatles came together. And then suddenly everyone started copying that.”

;

;Norman says Now and Then “is really a reminder of John's almost-isolation. He was talking to Yoko Ono saying 'why are people covering Paul's songs more than my songs'. His legacy is secure, but he was a very insecure person.”

; ;

;Tessler predicts that the release of Now and Then also has the potential to change the way the entire band's legacy is viewed, and how they are understood culturally. “Anyone who's 53 and under has lived in a world where there's no Beatles at all,” she says. “When they broke up in 1970 it wasn't particularly amicable. What I think this does is give them a chance to soften this breakup and make it more poignant. A natural ending – rather than it being four young angry men saying they don't want to work together any more.

;

;“This is an enduring friendship that's run the course of a lifetime. You can't erase history but it will give us a different understanding of the Beatles, who are still working together in some form from the 1960s through to 2023.”

;

;Visual artist Ed Ruscha has created the artwork for the single, while the music video to accompany the track is being helmed by Lord of the Rings and The Hobbit director Peter Jackson, who also directed the ;eight-hour Beatles documentary Get Back; in 2021 – the film used the same AI technology to pick apart recordings of songs for their final two albums, Abbey Road and Let It Be.

;

;The video is set to feature previously unseen footage of the band, given to Jackson by Olivia Harrison, Lennon's son Sean and Pete Best, the band's original drummer who left in 1962. Best, Jackson said, provided “a few precious seconds of the Beatles performing in their leather suits, the earliest known film of the Beatles and never seen before”.

;

;A separate 12-minute making-of film about the new song, Now and Then – The Last Beatles Song, is available on YouTube, and physical versions of Now and Then (on 12-inch and seven-inch vinyl, cassette and CD) are available to pre-order before going on sale on Friday. There will also be expanded and newly mixed versions of the compilations 1962-1966 and 1967-1970 (known as the Red and Blue albums) released on 10 November.

; Thu, 02 Nov 2023 13:52:01 +0800 Li Keqiang funeral in China brings out crowds despite suppression efforthttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/02/li-keqiang-funeral-in-china-brings-out-crowds-despite-suppression-effort
;;2023-11-02T03:44:58Z;
;
;;A woman looks out from a tricycle cart after policemen blocked the roads near the Babaoshan Revolutionary Cemetery in Beijing Thursday, 2 November 2023.
;

;Hundreds of people gathered near a state funeral home in China on Thursday as former premier Li Keqiang was being laid to rest.

;

;Plainclothes and uniformed police lined the roadway leading to the funeral home, blocking traffic and telling people to move along while watching for the presence of unofficial or foreign media.

;

;Public tributes to Li have been strictly controlled as the government seeks to prevent a mass outpouring of grief that it regards as a possible trigger for social unrest.

;

;But ;despite censorship targeting “overly effusive” comments and gatherings;, in Li's home city of Hefei, in Anhui province, hundreds of mourners laid flowers for one of their most significant sons over the weekend.

; ;

;The deaths of former premier Zhou Enlai in 1976, and of Hu Yaobang, a former CCP general secretary, in 1989, prompted widespread outpourings of grief that morphed into protests.

;

;More recently, the death of ;Covid whistleblower Li Wenliang ;in 2020, and a deadly ;apartment fire in Xinjiang; in 2022, have triggered expressions of public grief – with the latter becoming the “;white paper” protests; that spread across several cities.

;
;

;;Related: ;;China seeks to stifle public grief for former premier Li Keqiang;

;
;

;In Li's honour, flags at Tiananmen Square in the heart of Beijing were lowered to half mast, as well as at government and party offices around China and embassies and consulates abroad.

;

;“In memory of comrade Li Keqiang, flags were flown at half-mast at Tiananmen Square in the capital,” CCTV said in a report accompanied by a photo of the flag being lowered in front of the monumental gate against the backdrop of a foggy grey morning.

;

;Li died last Friday of a heart attack at age 68. State media had said he would be cremated on Thursday but did not mention funeral plans. According to precedent, retired high-level officials usually lie in state briefly as top leaders pass the body and offer wreaths of white flowers, the traditional colour of mourning.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Li Keqiang obituary;

;
;

;Li helped guide China's economy for a decade before being dropped from the Communist party's all-powerful politburo standing committee in October 2022. He left office in March 2023 despite being two years below the informal retirement age of 70.

;

;Though his time in office was marked by numerous crises, including the Covid-19 pandemic, he was seen as an alternative to the increasingly authoritarian party leader Xi Jinping. When Li became premier, the second most powerful position in China's leadership, in 2013, he carried hopes of embracing private enterprise and allowing the free market to flourish.

;

;But Li was left with little authority after Xi made himself the most powerful Chinese leader in decades and tightened control over the economy and society.

;

;Xi awarded himself a third five-year term as party leader and filled the top party ranks with loyalists. The role of premier was given to ;Li Qiang;, the party secretary for Shanghai, who lacked Li Keqiang's national level experience and later told reporters that his job was to do whatever Xi decided.

;

;;– With the Associated Press;

;China and the United States will reportedly discuss nuclear arms control next week, the first such talks since the Obama administration.

;

;The talks would be led on Monday by Mallory Stewart, a senior state department official, and Sun Xiaobo, the head of the arms control department at China's foreign ministry, the Wall Street Journal ;reported; on Wednesday.

;

;On Monday, China's foreign ministry said the two countries would hold “consultations on arms control and non-proliferation” in the coming days, as well as separate talks on maritime affairs and other issues. It follows a visit to Washington by the Chinese foreign minister, Wang Yi.

;

;The US state department and China's embassy in Washington did not immediately respond to requests by Reuters for comment on the timing or format of the talks.

;
;

;;Related: ;;China expanding nuclear arsenal much faster than predicted, US report says;

;
;

;The US national security adviser Jake Sullivan said in 2021 that the Chinese and US presidents had agreed to “look to begin to carry forward discussion on strategic stability”, a reference to Washington's concerns about Beijing's nuclear weapons buildup.

;

;But the White House was quick to say at the time that the discussions would not resemble formal arms reduction talks, like those the US has had with Russia.

;

;Since then, US officials have expressed frustration that China showed little interest in discussing steps to reduce nuclear weapons risks.

;

;China has more than 500 operational nuclear warheads in its arsenal and will probably have more than 1,000 warheads by 2030, the Pentagon said in October.但北京长期以来一直认为美国已经拥有更大的核武库。 ;Russia and the US together possess almost 90% of all the nuclear weapons globally;. ;

;Under the New Start treaty, Moscow and Washington are committed to deploying no more than 1,550 strategic nuclear warheads. Vladimir Putin said in February 2023 that Russia would halt its participation.

;

;The arms talks would occur before a likely meeting between the US president, Joe Biden, and the Chinese president, Xi Jinping, in San Francisco in November, although a senior Biden administration official said on Tuesday that important details were yet to be hammered out.

;

;A flurry of China-US diplomatic engagements in recent months, largely at Washington's request, has sought to salvage what were rapidly deteriorating ties between the two countries after the US downing in February of a suspected Chinese spy balloon over the United States.

;

;Daryl Kimball, executive director of the Washington-based Arms Control Association, said the overdue arms talks would likely focus on promoting greater transparency of each country's nuclear doctrines and more effective crisis communication channels.

;

;“I don't think, however, we should expect breakthroughs in the near term. That's going to take time and give and take from both sides,” Kimball said.

;

;Russia has shelled more than 100 settlements over the last 24 hours – more than in any single day so far this year – Ukraine has said as its commander-in-chief warns the war with Russia is moving towards a new stage of static and attritional fighting, a phase that could allow Moscow to rebuild its military power.

;

;It comes amid reports that North Korea has supplied Russia with two months' worth of artillery shells.

;

;The Russians have fired millions of shells on cities, towns and villages since invading in February 2022, reducing several settlements to rubble across the eastern part of Ukraine.

;

;“Over the last 24 hours, the enemy shelled 118 settlements in 10 regions,” Igor Klymenko, the Ukrainian interior minister, wrote on social media.

;

;“This is the highest number of cities and villages that have come under attack since the start of the year.”

;

;Ukraine also reported a Russian attack on an oil refinery in Kremenchuk, a central industrial city. There were no casualties but it took almost 100 firefighters several hours to put out the resulting fire, Klymenko said. The overnight shelling in the north-eastern Kharkiv region killed one person, and another was killed in the southern Kherson region, local officials said.

; ;

;Ukraine's government and the west fear Russia will escalate its attacks on Ukraine's energy infrastructure ahead of the cold winter, ;as it did last year;.

;

;Citing intelligence information, a South Korean lawmaker said on Wednesday that North Korea had provided Russia with more than a million badly needed artillery shells in exchange for advanced Russian technologies that would strengthen Kim's nuclear-armed military.

;
;

;;Related: ;;'Energy war': Ukraine tries to protect electricity supply before winter;

;
;

;In an article for the Economist published on Wednesday, Gen Valerii Zaluzhnyi said his army needed key new military capabilities and technological innovation to break out of the new phase of the war, now in its 21st month.
;
; Using stark language, he described risks of prolonged, attritional fighting: “This will benefit Russia, allowing it to rebuild its military power, eventually threatening Ukraine's armed forces and the state itself.”
;
; His article comes almost five months into a major Ukrainian counteroffensive that has not made a serious breakthrough against heavily mined Russian defensive lines. Fighting is expected to slow as the weather worsens.
;
; “Just like in the first world war we have reached the level of technology that puts us into a stalemate,” Zaluzhnyi was quoted as saying in an interview published alongside his article.

; ;

;The article singled out Russia's air power advantage as a factor that made advancing harder and called for Ukraine to conduct massive drone strikes to overload Russia's air defences.
;
; “Basic weapons, such as missiles and shells, remain essential. But Ukraine's armed forces need key military capabilities and technologies to break out of this kind of war. The most important one is air power,” he wrote.
;
; He called it a priority for Ukraine to build up its reserve forces despite noting it had limited capacity to train them inside the country and highlighting gaps in legislation that allowed people to evade service.
;
; “We are trying to fix these problems. We are introducing a unified register of draftees, and we must expand the category of citizens who can be called up for training or mobilisation.
;
; “We are also introducing a 'combat internship', which involves placing newly mobilised and trained personnel in experienced frontline units to prepare them.”

; ;

;As Ukraine hopes for better technology and additional funding from the west, South Korea's national intelligence service (NIS) said the North had been sending shells to Russia using ships and other transport means since early August. Those shells would roughly amount to two months' supply for the Russians, Yoo Sang-bum said. Yoo attended a closed-door briefing on Wednesday with intelligence officials.

;

;NIS officials didn't immediately respond to a request to confirm Yoo's account of the meeting. The agency has a mixed record on tracking developments in North Korea, which is made difficult by Pyongyang's stringent control of information. But North Korea and Russia have been actively boosting the visibility of their partnership in the face of separate, deepening confrontation with the US. Both Pyongyang and Moscow have denied US and South Korean claims that the North has been supplying arms to Russia.

;

;There are concerns in South Korea that North Korea could receive sensitive Russian technologies that would enhance the threat of Kim's nuclear weapons and missiles programme. But the NIS said it was more likely that the Russian assistance would be limited to conventional capabilities, possibly including efforts to improve North Korea's ageing fighter aircraft fleets, Yoo said.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Evidence mounts of North Korean arms to Russia in threat for Ukraine;

;
;

;The US, South Korea and Japan issued a joint statement on 26 October that strongly condemned what they described as North Korea's supply of arms to Russia, saying such shipments would sharply increase the human toll of Russia's aggression in Ukraine.

;

;The White House had earlier said North Korea delivered more than 1,000 containers of military equipment and munitions to Russia. The White House released images that it said showed the containers were loaded on to a Russian-flagged ship before being moved via train to south-western Russia.

;“The woman will now be interviewed by police and the investigation remains ongoing.”

;Technology dogs, which are often Labradors, are trained to smell the chemical triphenylphosphine oxide (TPPO) that is found on circuit boards, sim cards and hard drives.
